A quantitative_probability_distribution is a type of that represents the output of a that is a probability distribution. Every random variable gives rise to a probability distribution, and this distribution contains most of the important information about the variable. If X is a random variable, the corresponding probability distribution assigns to the interval [a, b] the probability Pr[a ≤ X ≤ b], i.e. the probability that the variable X will take a value in the interval [a, b].
The probability distribution of the variable X can be uniquely described by its cumulative distribution function F(x), which is defined by F(x)=Pr[X ≤ x] for any x in R.

A risk_criteria is a type of that identifies the terms of reference by which the significance of risk elements are assessed.
Risk criteria can be standards used to translate numerical risk estimates (e.g. 10-7 per year) into value judgements, for example 'negligible risk', that can be set against other value judgements such as 'high economic benefits' in a decision-making process.
Diferent risk_criteria may be applicable to different stakeholders or groups of stakeholders (e.g. safety risk to 1st, 2nd and 3rd parties).
Associated cost and benefits, legal and statutory requirements, socio-economic and environmental aspects, the concerns of stakeholders, and priorities to the assessment of risk are some of the various terms of reference of risk_criteria.
An individual fatality risk of '0.001' per year is an example of an individual risk_criteria. f-N curves (estimated relation between accident frequency and expected no. of facilities given an accident) may be used as for societal risk.

A risk_reduction is a type of taken to lessen the probability, negative consequences, or both, associated with a particular .
A can be used to structure and guide a subjective or code-based approach to risk reduction.
An example of risk_reduction is 'subjective approach', in which the decision-makers consider the range of possible actions, and select those that they believe are appropriate for the installation.
A second example of risk_reduction is 'code-based approach', in which measures are selected that conform to good engineering practice, according to relevant industry guidelines and codes of practice.
A third example of risk_reduction is 'risk criteria approach', in which the results of a risk analysis are compared with numerical risk criteria. In their most simple form, these indicate whether the activity is acceptable or not.
If it is unacceptable, then risk reduction measures must be adopted regardless of cost. If it is acceptable, then no further measures are needed.
A fourth example of risk_reduction is 'cost-benefit approach', in which measures are selected if they have a favourable ratio of benefit (i.e. risk reduction) to cost (i.e. capital expenditure and operating costs).
This is the most powerful and rational of the available approaches, providing objective guidance on specific risk reduction measures, while taking account of economic constraints.
A combination of example three and four is quite common, a cost-benefit approach is applied for a "band". Above the upper limit, the risk is unacceptable and has to be reduced if the activity shall be continued, and below the lower limit, the risk is considered acceptable without any further reduction.
